text.p: Here are highlights from Polish newspapers this morning.
FRONT PAGE POLITICAL NEWS
RZECZPOSPOLITA

- Right-wing parties will change the new constitution, if it is approved in a referendum in May and if they win parliamentary elections in September, the Movement for the Reconstruction of Poland's (ROP) leader Jan Olszewski said.
- The co-ruling Polish Peasant Party (PSL), which launched its electoral campaign over the weekend, will run separately in the polls.
- The centrist Union for Freedom is the most popular political party among Poland's elites, such as businessmen, politicians and those with free professions, according to a poll by CBOS agency.
- Human rights are respected in Poland and the overall situation is good, Amnesty International's secretary Julia Sherwood said.
ECONOMIC AND MAREKET STORIES
RZECZPOSPOLITA

- Improving cost-effectiveness of the farming sector and preparing the negotiations on the sector's integrataion with the EU are the priorities of the agriculture ministry, the newly appointed Agriculture Minister Jacek Kalinowski said.

- Poland's economy will benefit from foreign investment, reduced unemployment and inflation pushed down to 15 percent this year, a report by the EU representation in Warsaw said. The economy will not suffer from overheating, the report said.

- Poland's distilleries face a slump: the Polmos distillery in Raciborz, southern Poland, went bankrupt, a court-appointed management is now running the Polmos plant in Lodz, central Poland, six other plants lost liquidity and 10 distilleries do not generate profits. The slump may soon result in increased alcohol imports, Solidarity trade unions of the distillling industry said.

- Rentsch Poland cigarette packaging maker has invested $25 million in its Lodz plant development since 1994 and is now the biggest packaging firm in central and eastern Europe. The plant's sales were 90 million zlotys in the fiancial year 1996-1997. Rentsch is planning to expand further east and set up a similar plant in St. Pertersburg, Russia.
- Szeptel telecom firm located in Lomza province is preparing a financial memorandum required to list it on the over-the-counter (OTC) market, Szeptel's president Andrzej Wyszynski said.
DZIENNIK PRAWA I GOSPODARKI

- The general shareholders' meeting of Warta Vita life insurance firm will increase share capital by 4.5 million zlotys. Warta is in talks with a group of foreign investors interested in acquiring its shares.

- Rafineria Gdanska (RG), Poland's second biggest refinery, will increase output to 4.5 million tonnes in 1997 from three million tonnes last year, RG's president Wlodzimierz Dyrka said. The refinery now has a 22-percent market share, Dyrka said.
- Poland's insurance market has stabilised following a series of banruptcies last year and no more crashes are expected in the sector in 1997, some experts said.

- Norway's Orkla foods has acquired a 64 percent stake in the Kotlin vegetable and fruit processing firm in Kalisz province worth 36 million zlotys. Orkla will invest 16 million zlotys in plant development in the next six years.
ZYCIE
- The Polish branch of the U.S. Tenneco Automotive concern plans to buy a car shock absorber plant in Krosno, southeastern Poland.
